{{redirect|QueirÃ³s|other people|Queiroz (surname)}} [[Image:Pedro FernÃ¡ndez de QuirÃ³s.JPG|thumb|Pedro Fernandes de QueirÃ³s]] '''Pedro Fernandes de QueirÃ³s''' ({{lang-es|'''Pedro FernÃ¡ndez de QuirÃ³s'''}}), (1565â1614) was a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] navigator best known for his involvement with Spanish voyages of discovery in the [[Pacific Ocean]], in particular the 1595-1596 voyage of [[Alvaro de MendaÃ±a de Neira]], and for leading a 1605-1606 expedition which crossed the Pacific in search of [[Terra Australis]]. ==Early life== QueirÃ³s was born in [[Ãvora]], [[Portugal]] in 1565. As a young man he entered [[Spain|Spanish]] service and became an experienced seaman and navigator. In April 1595 he joined [[Ãlvaro de MendaÃ±a de Neira]] on his voyage to colonise the [[Solomon Islands]], serving as pilot. After MendaÃ±aâs death in October 1595 he is credited with taking command and saving the only remaining ship of the expedition, arriving in the [[Philippines]] in February 1596.[http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A020311b.htm Australian Dictionary of Biography online] ==The Search for Terra Australis== In 1598 QueirÃ³s returned to Spain and petitioned King [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III]] to support another voyage into the [[Pacific]]. A devout Catholic, QueirÃ³s also visited [[Rome]] in 1600, where he obtained the support of the Pope, [[Clement VIII]], for further explorations. He greatly impressed the Spanish Ambassador in [[Rome]], the Duke of Sesa, who described him as a âman of good judgement, experienced in his profession, hard working, quiet and disinterested.â While in Rome QueirÃ³s also first wrote his ''Treatise on Navigation'' as a letter to the king, further reinforcing his reputation as a navigator. In March 1603 QueirÃ³s was finally authorized to return to [[Peru]] to establish another expedition, with the intention of finding [[Terra Australis]], the mythical "great south land," and claiming it for [[Spain]] and the Church. QueirÃ³s's party of 160 men on three ships, ''San Pedro y San Pablo'' (150 tons), ''San Pedro'' (120 tons) and the tender (or launch) ''Los Tres Reyes'' left [[Callao]] on 21 December 1605.Estensen, M. (2006) ''Terra Australia Incognita; The Spanish Quest for the Great South Land'' p.111-113. Allen & Unwin, Australia ISBN 978 1741750546 In January 1606 the expedition discovered [[Henderson Island (Pitcairn Islands)|Henderson Island]] and [[Ducie Island]]. In May 1606 the expedition reached the islands later called the [[New Hebrides]] and now the independent nation of [[Vanuatu]]. QueirÃ³s landed on a large island which he took to be part of the southern continent, and named it ''La Austrialia No, not a typo! See accounts of the voyage cited, eg Estensen, M (2006) del Espiritu Santo'' (The Austrian Land of the Holy Spirit), for King [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III]], who was of Austrian descent. The island is still called [[Espiritu Santo]]. Here he stated his intention to establish a colony, to be called Nova Jerusalem. QueirÃ³s's religious fervour found expression with the founding of a new Order of Chivalry, the Knights of the Holy Ghost. The Orderâs purpose was to protect the new colony. However, within weeks the idea of a colony was abandoned due to the hostility of the Ni-Vanuatu and to disagreements among the crew. After six weeks QueirÃ³s's ships put to sea to explore the coastline. On the night of June 11, 1606 QueirÃ³s in the ''San Pedro y San Pablo'' became separated from the other ships in bad weather and was unable (or so he later said) to return to safe anchorage at [[Espiritu Santo]]. He then sailed to [[Acapulco]] in [[Mexico]], where he arrived in November 1606. In the account of Diego de Prado y Tovar, which is highly critical of QueirÃ³s, mutiny and poor leadership is given as the reason for QueirÃ³s's disappearance.[http://www.sl.nsw.gov.au/discover_collections/history_nation/voyages/voya_spanishQuest.html Prado's Account can be read online] Two weeks later, his second-in-command, [[Luis VÃ¡ez de Torres]], after searching in vain for QueirÃ³s and assuming his ship was wrecked, left [[Espiritu Santo]]. Torres successfully reached [[Manila]], the center of the [[Spanish East Indies]] in May 1607, charting the southern coastline of [[New Guinea]] on the way and in doing so sailing through the strait that now bears his name. ==QueirÃ³s in later life== Pedro de QueirÃ³s returned to Madrid in 1607. Regarded as a crank, he spent the next seven years writing numerous accounts of his voyage and begging King [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III]] for money for a new voyage. He was finally despatched to [[Peru]] with letters of support, but the king had no real intention of funding another expedition. QueirÃ³s died on the way, in [[Panama]], in 1614. He had married Dona Ana Chacon of [[Madrid]] in 1589, who bore him one son and one daughter. ==Accounts of QueirÃ³s's Voyage== There are a number of documents describing the QueirÃ³s â Torres voyages still in existence. Dalrymple provided a sketch map which included the QueirÃ³s -Torres voyages to [[Joseph Banks]] who undoubtedly passed this information to [[James Cook]].Hilder, B (1980) p.31Estensen, M.(2006)p.222 ==Theory that QueirÃ³s discovered Australia== In the 19th century some Australian Catholics, living under a Protestant ascendancy, claimed that QueirÃ³s had in fact discovered Australia, in advance of the Protestants [[Willem Janszoon]], [[Abel Tasman]] and [[James Cook]]. The Archbishop of [[Sydney]] from 1884 to 1911, [[Patrick Francis Moran]], asserted this to be a fact, and it was taught in Catholic schools for many years.Moran, cited in Richardson, W.A.R.
